review.title: A multinomial probabilistic model for movie genre predictions
review.abstract: This paper proposes a movie genre-prediction based on multinomial probability model. To the best of our knowledge, this problem has not been addressed yet in the field of recommender system. The prediction of a movie genre has many practical applications including complementing the items categories given by experts and providing a surprise effect in the recommendations given to a user. We employ mulitnomial event model to estimate a likelihood of a movie given genre and the Bayes rule to evaluate the posterior probability of a genre given a movie. Experiments with the MovieLens dataset validate our approach. We achieved 70% prediction rate using only 15% of the whole set for training.

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: Recommender systems are tools whose purpose is to help users overcome information overload by selecting the most interesting information based on users "preferences and helping companies sell more products. In this article, we suggested predicting a movie genre rather than predicting movie ratings. To this end, we used Nave Baye's classifier and a multinomial event model previously used for text classification and a number of other tasks. This approach can potentially improve the efficiency of recommendations by recommending movies from unexpected but relevant genres; this will be investigated in further research. We showed that the genre prediction rate increases as the size of training data increases, but the prediction rate slows down. Even a small number of users enables a significant increase in genre prediction. Overall, we have successfully applied ratings for genre predictions in the context of movies.
